awd_titl_txt: Efficient, accurate and rapidly convergent algorithms for solutions of wave propagation problems in configurations complex material and geometrical features
awd_abstract_narration:
Turc
DMS-1008076

     The investigator develops efficient, accurate and rapidly
convergent algorithms for evaluation of the interaction between
electromagnetic fields and complex structures.  Specifically, the
investigator and his collaborators develop a family of algorithms
that focus mainly on (1) Fast, high-order numerical solutions for
wave-propagation problems in domains that contain geometric
singularities, and (2) Scattering problems from penetrable
electromagnetic periodic structures, with a particular emphasis
on resonant problems relevant to the design of photonic crystals
and Negative Index Materials (NIM).  The investigator
concentrates on development and implementation of a massively
parallel computational framework based on integral equation
formulations capable of producing fast and high-order solutions
of wave scattering problems of realistic complexity.  The
approach consists of the following main elements: (a) High-order
resolution of the singularities of the solutions of the boundary
integral equations in non-smooth domains; (b)
Pseudodifferential-calculus-based design and analysis of
well-conditioned integral equation formulations leading to small
numbers of Krylov-subspace iterations for a wide range of
electromagnetic transmission problems; and (c) Use of equivalent
sources, FFT-based acceleration algorithms, and implementations
that take advantage of the newly available Graphic Processing
Units (GPUs) computational platforms to dramatically enhance
computational times and capabilities. 

     The algorithms that are developed as part of this project
are of fundamental significance to diverse applications such as
electromagnetic interference and compatibility (electronic
circuits), dielectric/magnetic coated conductors, and composite
meta-materials (photonic crystals and Negative Index Materials). 
The simulation of electromagnetic wave propagation in complex
structures gives rise to a host of significant computational
challenges that result from non-coercive formulations,
oscillatory solutions, geometric singularities, resonances, and
ill-conditioning in the high-frequency regime.  The recent
efforts of the investigator and his collaborators resulted in the
development of a highly efficient computational methodology that
resolved several of these difficulties and whose extension
enables the fulfillment of an ambitious plan: to simulate with
high fidelity realistic scattering environments with a high
dynamic range.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of the project ``Efficient, accurate and rapidly convergent algorithms for solutions of wave propagation problems in configurations complex material and geometrical features" are the design, analysis, and high-end implementation of a suite of algorithms capable of simulating the interaction of electromagnetic waves with large-scale and materially complex structures (see the Sentry aircraft figure for an illustration of the capability of the solvers developed in this project).

The algorithms developed as part of this project  use complex mathematical tools that lead to mathematical formulations of important physics and engineering problems (e.g. Maxwell equations in realistic environments)  whose solutions can be simulated numerically with great efficiency. Some of these algorithms are at the frontier of computational electromagnetics. Notably, for the first time in this field, the PI and collaborators were able to overcome a major obstacle that has confronted numerical methods based on integral equations for solution of wave propagation in periodic media (e.g photonic crystals). This difficulty is related to certain resonant phenomena in wave propagation problems in three dimensional periodic media (i.e. Wood anomalies). The algorithms developed in this project impact upon a variety of areas of societal interest, including the electrical engineering (electronic circuits) and meta-materials science (photonic crystals and negative index materials).  Four undergraduate students (all of whom are currently graduate students in Mathematics) and three graduate students were involved in this project.

The specific outcomes of this project are summarized in what follows. The PI has introduced well-conditioned integral formulations of scattering problems for the case when the material properties of the scatterer are modelled by Neumann boundary conditions. These formulations were implemented by the PI in both two and three dimensions, and in the case when the scatterer has features such as corners and edges. In addition, the PI has analyzed some very important features (i.e coercivity) that the integral equations possess, features that lead to short computational times of their implementation. The PI extended the work recounted above to the case of wave interactions with penetrable obstacles and presented a general strategy to obtain integral equations with optimal properties. Finally, the PI introduced an algorithm for fast evaluation of quasi-periodic Green's functions that works throughout certain resonances (i.e Wood anomalies) that arise in periodic media.
